comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I'm taking a gamble here but I think that the trophy on the left as you face it is the Metropolitan Cup for coxed fours from the Dublin Metropolitan Regatta.  This is one of the most prestigious trophies in  Irish rowing and is also known as "The Blue Riband".  It was also recognised as the unofficial fours championship of Ireland.  I will send a link to someone in the rowing fraternity and see if they can identify it.  If that is the cup, or 'pot'  as they are known, the the names of the crew are likely to be inscribed on it.  As far as I know Waterford Boat Club are still active and they had a great selection of old photos on display in their clubhouse so they may have the record also?  Lets see how we get on?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Brilliant! We'll await developments. Have added pots as a tag...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 22575440@N07
comment._content: whoever they were, they needed some undergarments.... : 0

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Tammybeck, how could you;-)  A bit like cycling, when sitting on the sliding seat in the boats, having seams across your backside could be very painful over time.  When I was rowing there was a special seat in the shorts and today with spandex etc. there are no seams.  I suspect that the absence of underwear was to minimise discomfort.

comment._content:
The cox, centre, is my great uncle, Austin Farrell, 1872-1934. see also other photographs....I have no information on the other gentlemen. (yet!)
NLI Ref.: P_WP_1544a

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38524172@N08] Hi Brendan. Have added your identification above, and thank you very much for it! Were you aware that we have that Chamber of Commerce photo on here. Your great uncle, Austin Farrell, had already been identified on it... Swapped this pic for a higher res version too - hopefully that'll make identification easier.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38524172@N08] Just thinking, if your great uncle Austin was born in 1872, how old do you think he would have been in this photo? We had a tentative date of circa 1897 on this one, but that would make Austin 25 years old in this photo, so that date can't be right. He looks about 16 or so to me, which would place this photo somewhere in the 1880s. What do you think?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: At the end of the Oxford & Cambridge boat race they throw their cox into the Thames.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] The tradition started with THE Boat Race where the winning crew chucked the Cox into the Thames.  This was taken up by other clubs over the years but a lot depended on the cox and the occasion.  In latter years that tradition was banned in the Thames because of the risk of infection but with improved water quality it may be done all over again.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The Rowers limerick A team of young Waterford rowers Were known as outstanding 'mo' growers. What gave them the edge? Daily meat and two veg - Turning rowers from growers to showers.
